Graphical abstract Spin-state engineered NiCo2O4@NF enables selective glucose electrooxidation to formic acid (80.7% yield, 91.3% FE) with concurrent efficient H2 evolution (696 μmol h−1, 99.9% FE) via tetrahedral Ni-induced intermediate-spin Co3+ sites. Electrocatalytic glucose oxidation to high-value chemicals provides a sustainable route for biomass valorization. NiCo-based catalysts have emerged as promising candidates for glucose oxidation reaction owing to the intrinsic activity of Ni and Co catalytic centers. However, the dynamic evolution and atomic-scale synergy between these centers remain elusive. Herein, we fabricated NiCo2O4 nanosheets supported on nickel foam, where Ni preferentially occupies tetrahedral sites to regulate the electronic configuration of octahedral Co. Experimental and theoretical results demonstrate that the incorporation of tetrahedral Ni induces low-to-intermediate spin transition in octahedral Co, thereby optimizing e g orbital occupancy and stabilizing active sites. This spin-state engineering establishes Ni-Co synergistic catalytic centers for the selective oxidation of glucose to formic acid. At higher potential (≥1.4 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode), octahedral Co undergoes reconstruction into excessive active CoOOH and CoO2 species, resulting in glucose overoxidation to CO2 and intensified competitive oxygen evolution. In contrast, at lower potentials (<1.4 V), tetrahedral Ni facilitates electron delocalization across the Ni–O–Co lattice, thereby stabilizing octahedral Co for glucose adsorption and oxidation. Subsequently, a coupled electrocatalytic system was constructed, achieving 80.7% formic acid yield with 91.3% Faradaic efficiency at NiCo2O4 anode and H2 evolution rate of 696 μmol h−1 with 99.9% Faradaic efficiency at Pt cathode for 2 h under 1.35 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode. This work provides a deep insight into spin-state regulation of the catalytic center, offering valuable guidance for rational catalyst design. Keywords Electrocatalysis Glucose oxidation Biomass valorization Spin-state regulation Formic acid 1 Introduction The conversion of biomass into value-added chemicals presents a promising approach for achieving sustainable energy systems and carbon neutrality [1–3]. As a ubiquitous plant-derived biomass, glucose serves as an abundant feedstock for producing valuable chemicals through selective electrochemical valorization [4]. The electrocatalytic glucose oxidation reaction (GOR) enables simultaneous chemical production and energy harvesting by: i) direct synthesis of high-value chemicals such as gluconic acid, glycolic acid, and formic acid (FA) [5], and ii) efficient co-generation of hydrogen or ammonia via coupled cathodic reactions [6]. Despite these advantages, the practical application of GOR faces multifaceted challenges including reactor design, product separation, feedstock availability and catalyst performance [7]. Among these, the development of high-efficiency electrocatalysts constitutes a fundamental bottleneck. Noble metal catalysts (e.g., Pt, Au, Pd) incur prohibitive costs and suffer from catalyst poisoning, while monometallic transition metal oxides (e.g., NiO, Co3O4) exhibit sluggish kinetics and severe performance degradation under alkaline conditions [8,9]. These limitations necessitate the rational design of cost-effective electrocatalysts with high activity, selectivity, and operational durability for GOR. Bimetallic synergistic effects demonstrate significant utility in critical energy technologies, particularly oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and rechargeable Zn-air batteries [10]. Tailored bimetallic catalysts enhance oxygen evolution/reduction kinetics in Zn-air systems, improving energy conversion efficiency while reducing carbon emission intensity and facilitating renewable energy storage within carbon-neutral frameworks [11]. Extending these strategies to biomass valorization, electrocatalytic glucose oxidation reaction (GOR) leverages bimetallic synergy for enhanced performance. For instance, CoNi-layered double hydroxide (LDH)/Ni systems leverage Co-Ni synergy to enhance charge transfer efficiency and modulate d-band center positions, significantly accelerating reaction kinetics [12]. High-entropy FeCoNiCu-LDH/NF achieves >90% glucaric acid yield through multi-site cascade catalysis [13]. NiO/NiCo2O4 heterojunctions enable a 72% FA yield with concurrent hydrogen evolution via interfacial charge redistribution in integrated GOR-HER (hydrogen evolution reaction) systems [14]. Nanostructured CuCo2O4 spinel oxides further deliver superior GOR performance, achieving a high current density of 500 mA cm−2 at 1.40 V vs. RHE (reversible hydrogen electrode) with 98% Faradaic efficiency (FE) for formate [15]. Critically, employing CuCo2O4 catalysts in a two-electrode GOR-HER system reduces the cell voltage by 370 mV compared to conventional water electrolysis at 200 mA cm−2, highlighting the substantial energy efficiency potential of this integrated approach for co-producing hydrogen and value-added chemicals. Despite these advances, the atomic-scale mechanism of bimetallic synergy and the dynamic evolution of active sites during GOR remain elusive, impeding the rational design of high-performance electrocatalysts. Spinel oxides provide an ideal platform for understanding structure-activity relationships in electrocatalysis due to their compositional and structural flexibility [16]. These materials adopt three primary configurations based on cation distribution: normal, inverse, and complex spinels [17]. In normal spinels, divalent cations (e.g., Ni2+, Zn2+, and Cu2+) occupy tetrahedral sites, while trivalent cations (e.g., Co3+, Fe3+, and Al3+) occupy octahedral sites. Conversely, in inverse spinels, half of the trivalent cations occupy tetrahedral sites, with the remaining trivalent and all divalent cations occupying octahedral sites. Frequent cation exchange between tetrahedral and octahedral sites allows for tunable inversion degrees [18], which enhance ionic transport by reducing electrostatic energy [19]. The degree of inversion is influenced by the combination and nature of metal cations, and the synthesis conditions [20], resulting in a structure that typically represents a combination of normal and inverse spinels. This structural flexibility enables precise modulation of material properties. For example, in Co3O4, the characteristic Co2+–O–Co3+ bonding network permits strategic heteroatom substitution (e.g., Ni2+ for Co2+). Such substitution induces lattice strain and promotes oxygen vacancies (Vo) formation [21,22], redistributing charge density to optimize the e g orbital occupancy of octahedral Co3+ [23]. These modulations enhance charge transfer kinetics and stabilize reactive intermediates via optimized d-band centers [24]. However, prior studies have predominantly focused on OER, whereas the role of Ni-Co synergy in spinel oxides for selective GOR remains largely unexplored. Herein, we synthesized normal spinel NiCo2O4 nanosheets supported on nickel foam substrates (NiCo2O4@NF) via electrochemical co-deposition followed by thermal annealing. Through comprehensive experimental and theoretical analysis, we disclose that tetrahedral Ni2+ modulates the electronic environment of octahedral Co3+, inducing a transition from a low-spin to an intermediate-spin state. This modulation optimizes the e g orbital occupancy of octahedral Co3+ and stabilizes its structure, thereby enhancing glucose adsorption. Importantly, octahedral Co3+ sites govern the selective glucose oxidation to formic acid at low-to-moderate potentials (<1.4 V vs. RHE), whereas at higher potentials, octahedral Co3+ undergos in situ structural transformation into CoOOH/CoO2 species, which leads to glucose overoxidation and intensifies the competing oxygen evolution reaction. As a result, the engineered NiCo2O4@NF catalyst achieves an outstanding FA yield of 80.7% with FE of 91.3% at 1.35 V vs. RHE in a coupled GOR-HER system operating for 2 h, while the Pt cathode delivers hydrogen production with 99.9% FE (yield rate of 696 μmol h−1), demonstrating efficient charge utilization. This work establishes a generalizable framework for designing spinel-based catalysts, advancing efficient and selective biomass valorization through atomic-scale control of geometric and electronic configurations. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All chemicals, including Ni foam (NF, 1 mm thickness, 110 ppi, SCI Materials Hub), planar nickel foil (1 mm thickness, SCI Materials Hub), cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, ≥99.0%, Macklin), nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, ≥98.0%, SCR), sodium hydroxide (NaOH, ≥96.0%, SCR), hydrochloric acid (HCl, 36%–38%, SCR), pivalic acid (C5H10O2, ≥99.9%, Rhawn), formic acid (CH2O2, 85%, Macklin), d-glucose (C6H12O6, ≥99.8%, Biotopped), ethanol (C2H6O, ≥99.5%, SCR), acetone (C3H6O, ≥99.5%, SCR), deuterium oxide (D2O, ≥99.9%, Sigma-Aldrich), were purchased and used without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of NiCo2O4@NF The NiCo2O4 electrocatalyst was fabricated on NF through a controlled synthesis protocol involving electrochemical co-deposition and heat treatment. NF substrate (2 cm × 3 cm) underwent sequential ultrasonic cleaning in 1 M HCl (10 min), ethanol (5 min), and acetone (5 min), followed by thorough rinsing with deionized water. Electrochemical deposition was performed in a three-electrode system using a CHI-650E workstation, with NF as the working electrode, a saturated Ag/AgCl reference electrode, and platinum foil (1.5 cm × 3 cm) counter electrode. The electrolyte contained 50 mM Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.4366 g) and 50 mM Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.4362 g) dissolved in 30 mL deionized water. Chronoamperometric deposition at −1.0 V (vs. Ag/AgCl) for 300 s generated the [Ni x Co y ]OOH@NF precursor, which was subsequently calcined in air (300°C, 3 h, 5°C min−1 heating rate) to obtain crystalline NiCo2O4@NF. Planar nickel foil was employed as the deposition substrate to facilitate catalyst harvesting for element composition analysis. 2.3 Preparation of Co3O4@NF and NiO@NF For comparative studies, Co3O4@NF and NiO@NF were synthesized under identical processing conditions with sole modification of the electrolyte composition. Specifically, 100 mM aqueous solutions of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.8732 g in 30 mL) and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.8724 g in 30 mL) were employed as precursors for Co3O4@NF and NiO@NF, respectively. All other parameters including deposition potential, calcination protocol and substrate dimensions remained consistent with the NiCo2O4@NF synthesis procedure. 2.4 Materials characterization The crystalline structures of the catalysts were analyzed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD, Rigaku SmartLab SE) using Cu K α radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å, 40 kV, 40 mA) with a scanning rate of 2° min−1 in the 2θ range of 10°–90°. Element composition was analyzed using inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Agilent 5110) with matrix-matched calibration standards. Morphological characterizations were performed using field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, ZEISS Sigma 300, 5 kV) coupled with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM, FEI Talos F200x, 200 kV). Selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns were recorded by a Gatan charge-coupled device (CCD) camera in a digital format. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha) with monochromatic Al K α source (1486.6 eV) was employed to investigate surface compositions and chemical states, with binding energies calibrated against the C 1s peak at 284.8 eV. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker EMX-Plus spectrometer at ambient temperature. For each measurement, 10 mg of catalyst powder was loaded into a quartz EPR tube (4 mm inner diameter) and gently compacted to ensure consistent sample packing density. In situ Raman measurements were conducted using a custom-designed electrochemical cell (PVDF body, quartz window) integrated with a confocal Raman spectrometer (Zolix RTS-II). A 532 nm diode laser (20 mW, 10% power density) focused through a 50× objective provided 1 μm spatial resolution. Near edge X-ray absorption spectra (NEXAFS) were collected at the XAFCA beamline of Singapore Synchrotron Light Source (SSLS) in transmission model, with the storage ring operating at 0.7 GeV and an electron current of ∼200 mA under top-up conditions. 2.5 Electrochemical measurement All electrochemical measurements were conducted using a CHI-650E workstation. An Ag/AgCl electrode filled with saturated KCl solution served as the reference electrode, while the as-synthesized NF-supported catalysts (geometric area: 5.0 cm2) acted as the working electrodes. A platinum foil (1.5 cm × 3 cm) was used as the counter electrode. For the OER and GOR, the electrolytes were 1 M NaOH (pH ≈ 13.63) and 1 M NaOH with 20 mM glucose, respectively. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was performed by applying a positive potential sweep at a scan rate of 2 mV s−1 at room temperature under vigorous stirring. The electrochemical data were corrected for iR drop using 85% compensation. Tafel slopes were extracted from the LSV curves. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves were recorded at various scan rates in the non-faradaic region to determine the electrochemical double-layer capacitance (C dl). The C dl value was calculated as the slope of the linear regression fit of Δj versus scan rate (v), as shown in Eq. (1) (1) Slope = C dl = d ( Δ j ) d v = d ( j a - j c 2 ) d v where j a and j c denote the anodic and cathodic current densities, respectively, measured at the midpoint of the potential window. Operando electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) tests were carried out using CHI-650E in a three-electrode system under different potentials over the frequency range from 105 to 10−1 Hz with an amplitude of 5 mV in 1 M NaOH with/without 20 mM glucose. The exchange-correlation interactions were described by the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [27], augmented by Grimme’s DFT-D3 dispersion correction for van der Waals interactions [28]. A plane-wave energy cutoff of 520 eV and a Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid of 2 × 2 × 1 were employed for Brillouin zone integration [29]. Structural optimizations proceeded until atomic forces fell below 0.01 eV Å−1 and total energy differences reached 1 × 10−5 eV between consecutive iterations. To address strong electron correlation effects in transition metal oxides, the DFT+U approach was implemented with Hubbard parameters U = 3.0 eV (Co 3d) and U = 5.5 eV (Ni 3d) [30]. Catalytically active surfaces were modeled as NiO (220), Co3O4 (440) and NiCo2O4 (440) slabs with 15 Å vacuum layers to eliminate periodic interactions. Spin-polarized calculations were performed for all systems. Charge transfer analysis was performed using the Bader partitioning scheme on the converged charge density distributions [31]. The adsorption energy (E ad) of glucose was calculated using the following Eq. (8) (8) E ad = E total - ( E slab + E mol where E total is the total energy of the adsorbed system, E slab is the energy of the clean substrate surface, and E mol is the energy of the isolated glucose molecule. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of NiCo-based electrocatalysts: structure, chemical state, and morphology A schematic illustration of the overall fabrication process is shown in Fig. 1(a) . Initially, the [Ni x Co y ]OOH@NF precursor was in situ electrodeposited on clean NF, followed by a one-step annealing process in air to yield NiCo2O4@NF. For comparison, the NiO@NF and Co3O4@NF samples were prepared using the corresponding Ni- or Co-containing electrolytes under identical conditions. To eliminate interference from the intense Ni substrate peaks (Fig. S1), catalyst powders were scraped from Ni foil substrates for structural characterization. The crystalline phases of the synthesized catalysts were analyzed by PXRD (Fig. 1b). All diffraction peaks match standard patterns for cubic NiO (PDF#47-1049), spinel Co3O4 (PDF#43-1003), and spinel NiCo2O4 (PDF # 20-0781). The isostructural nature of NiCo2O4 and Co3O4 arises from the comparable ionic radii (Ni2+ = 0.55 Å; Co2+ = 0.58 Å; Ni3+ = 0.60 Å; Co3+ = 0.61 Å) and redox potentials (E Ni o = −0.257 V, E Co o = −0.28 V), enabling partial Ni substitution without much distorting the cubic spinel framework [32]. The absence of inverse spinel diffraction features (e.g., characteristic peaks at ∼48.9° and ∼73.8°) [21] confirms that the synthesized NiCo2O4 adopts a normal spinel configuration (Fig. S2). Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) results uncover a Co/Ni atomic ratio of 1.93 in NiCo2O4, consistent with its nominal stoichiometry. Crystallite sizes were calculated via Scherrer's equation (D = kλ/βcosθ) using the (200) peak for NiO and the (311) peak for Co3O4/NiCo2O4. The derived sizes were 9.4 nm (NiO), 18.7 nm (Co3O4) and 8.5 nm (NiCo2O4). The reduced crystallite size of NiCo2O4 compared to Co3O4 is attributed to Ni incorporation, which restricts Co oxide grain growth and induces lattice strain. This strain is further evidenced by the broadened diffraction peaks observed in NiCo2O4 relative to Co3O4 (Fig. S3), reflecting microstructural distortions in the cubic spinel framework. To complement the PXRD-derived structural insights and probe the local bonding characteristics, Raman spectroscopy was systematically employed to analyze NiO@NF, Co3O4@NF and NiCo2O4@NF (Fig. 1c). For NiO@NF, characteristic peaks at 400, 520, 702, 890, and 1072 cm−1 correspond to the one-phonon (1P) transverse optical mode (TO), longitudinal optical (LO) phonon modes, two-phonon (2P) 2TO modes, LO+TO coupling and 2LO modes, respectively [33]. The observed Raman activity of LO and TO phonons originates from defect-induced lattice distortions and rhombohedral symmetry deviations in NiO below its Néel temperature (TN) [34]. In contrast, Co3O4@NF and NiCo2O4@NF exhibit distinct vibrational modes associated with metal-oxygen bonding. The Raman spectra of Co3O4@NF (NiCo2O4@NF) display peaks at 194 (191), 475 (470), 518 (513), 613 (595), and 678 (662) cm−1, assigned to the F1 2g, Eg, F2 2g, F3 2g, and A1g modes, respectively. These modes reflect the vibrational signatures of Co–O and Ni–O bonds within the spinel structure [35]. Specifically, the A1g mode in Co3O4@NF originates from the symmetric stretching vibration of octahedral Co–O2− bonds [CoO6], which involves the vibration of oxygen atoms along the c-axis [36], while the Eg mode corresponds to the asymmetric bending vibration of these bonds in the ab-plane [37]. The F 2g modes arise from coupled vibrations of tetrahedral Co–O2− bonds [CoO4] and octahedral oxygen motions [38]. Generally, Ni preferentially substitutes the tetrahedral Co [CoO4] sites [39], resulting in a red shift of the F2g vibration modes, as confirmed in this study. Notably, the A1g mode in NiCo2O4@NF also exhibits a red shift compared to Co3O4@NF, which correlated with the lattice strain identified in PXRD analysis (Fig. 1b). This lattice strain weakens Co–O bond strength and promotes the formation of oxygen vacancy (Vo), thereby enhancing electrical conductivity and active site accessibility [40]. To further validate this hypothesis, EPR and XPS analyses were conducted. EPR spectra of all catalysts exhibit a distinct signal at g = 2.003 (Fig. S4), characteristic of paramagnetic Vo [41]. To quantify Vo density, the spin density derived from EPR intensity was normalized to the oxygen content of each catalyst (Table S1). The normalized values reveal that NiCo2O4@NF possesses the highest Vo density (5.36 × 1021), surpassing NiO@NF (3.80 × 1021) and Co3O4@NF (3.42 × 1021). This result confirms that lattice strain induced by Ni incorporation facilitates Vo formation. XPS analysis further corroborates this trend (Fig. 1d, e). Survey spectra show no extraneous elemental impurities except adventitious carbon (Fig. S5). High-resolution O 1s spectra (Fig. 1e) resolve lattice oxygen (Oa, ∼529.5 eV) and surface chemisorbed oxygen (Ob, ∼531.1 eV). Ob includes contributions from defect-related oxide species (O2 2− or O−), hydroxyl groups, and absorbed water [36,42]. The Ob/Oa ratio, a metric for surface Vo quantification [43], increases from 1.02 (Co3O4@NF) to 2.22 (NiCo2O4@NF) (Fig. 1d, Table S2), directly correlating with the elevated Vo density observed in EPR. The electronic modulation induced by Ni incorporation is further elucidated through Co 2p and Ni 2p spectra. Deconvolution of Co 2p spectra (Fig. 1f) reveals a reduced Co2+/Co3+ ratio in NiCo2O4@NF (0.93) compared to Co3O4@NF (1.27), accompanied by distinct binding energy shifts: Co3+ peaks downshift by −0.1 eV, while Co2+ (Co 2p 3/2) peak upshifts by +0.3 eV. These shifts originate from Ni-induced structural and electronic perturbations. Tetrahedral Ni2+ substitution introduces lattice strain and polarizes adjacent oxygen atoms, thereby weakening Co–O bonds and lowering the energy barrier for Vo formation. The resultant Vo sites act as electron acceptors, oxidizing neighboring Co2+ to Co3+ to restore charge neutrality. Ni 2p spectra demonstrate a higher Ni2+/Ni3+ ratio in NiCo2O4@NF (0.85) than in NiO@NF (0.76) (Fig. 1d, g), with Ni2+ showing a positive binding energy shift (Δ = 0.4–0.6 eV). This reflects the electron-deficient nature of tetrahedral Ni ([NiO4]), which enhances oxygen polarization and further weakens Co–O bonds, thereby promoting Vo formation. Collectively, these results illustrate that Ni incorporation synergistically modifies geometric strain and electronic structure. Such modifications are expected to influence morphological features and enhance interfacial reactivity, as corroborated by subsequent microscopic characterizations. SEM images reveal distinct architectural differences among the catalysts (Fig. 2 ). NiO@NF exhibits densely packed nanoparticles with a rough surface morphology (Fig. 2a), which may impede ion/electron transport due to limited interfacial connectivity. In contrast, both Co3O4@NF and NiCo2O4@NF feature three-dimensional hierarchical frameworks composed of interconnected wrinkle-like nanosheets (Fig. 2d, g). The nanosheet size of NiCo2O4@NF (∼300 nm) is markedly smaller than that of Co3O4@NF (∼1 μm), consistent with its reduced crystallite size (8.5 vs. 18.7 nm) derived from PXRD analysis (Fig. 1b). This architecture is conductive to generating abundant mesoporous channels, enhancing active sites accessibility and facilitating efficient ion/electron transport [44]. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms further characterize the pore structures (Fig. S6). NiO@NF exhibits the highest BET specific surface area (120.48 m2 g−1) among the three catalysts (Table S3). Despite this, its predominantly microporous structure (micropores accounting for ∼50.5% of the surface area) and the lowest total pore volume may hinder glucose diffusion and adsorption. Conversely, NiCo2O4@NF possesses a higher BET specific surface area (72.29 m2 g−1) than Co3O4@NF (67.56 m2 g−1), with a hierarchical mesoporous network (2–50 nm) constituting 99.6% of its total pore volume (0.21 cm3 g−1) and an average pore diameter of 9.02 nm. These structural metrics confirm that reduced nanosheet dimensions increase the specific surface area and expose more catalytically active edge sites. Combined with the Vo-enriched surface, these morphological advantages synergistically optimize interfacial reactivity. Elemental mapping confirms the homogeneous distribution of Ni, Co and O across all catalyst surfaces (Fig. 2a, d, g), indicating well-mixed metal oxide phases without elemental segregation. Atomic-scale structural analysis via HRTEM and SAED provides further insights. For NiO@NF, lattice spacings of 0.208 nm and 0.241 nm correspond to the (200) and (111) planes, respectively (Fig. 2b, Fig. S7c). Co3O4@NF exhibits lattice spacings of 0.468, 0.286, and 0.244 nm, assigned to the (111), (220), and (311) planes of the cubic spinel structure (Fig. 2e, Fig. S7f). NiCo2O4@NF shows lattice spacings of 0.47, 0.294, 0.248, and 0.207 nm, matching the (111), (220), (311), and (400) planes of the spinel phase (Fig. 2h, Fig. S7i). SAED patterns (Fig. 2c, f, i) display polycrystalline diffraction rings consistent with XRD and Raman results, further verifying the crystallinity and phase purity of the synthesized metal oxides. Collectively, these structural advantages in NiCo2O4@NF establish a robust foundation for efficient charge transfer and enhanced catalytic activity, as quantified in subsequent electrochemical analysis. 3.2 Electrochemical performance of glucose oxidation The electrocatalytic performance of NiO@NF, Co3O4@NF, and NiCo2O4@NF was systematically evaluated in a three-electrode system using 1.0 M NaOH as the electrolyte, with and without 20 mM glucose (GOR and OER conditions, respectively). LSV results (Fig. 3a , Fig. S8) reveal significantly enhanced current densities and reduced onset potentials for glucose oxidation (solid lines) compared to OER condition (dashed lines), highlighting the thermodynamic and kinetic advantages of GOR over OER. Under OER condition, NiO@NF exhibits two distinct oxidation peaks at 1.39 V and 1.42 V vs. RHE, assigned to sequential Ni2+ → Ni3+ → Ni4+ transitions. Likewise, Co3O4@NF shows redox features at 1.41 and 1.47 V vs. RHE, corresponding to sequential Co2+ → Co3+ → Co4+ transitions. In contrast, NiCo2O4@NF displays two prominent oxidation peaks at 1.38 and 1.45 V vs. RHE with markedly higher current densities, indicating a higher density of accessible active sites compared to NiO@NF and Co3O4@NF. The dominant peak at 1.38 V arises from the concurrent oxidation of Ni2+ and Co2+ to their trivalent states, reflecting synergistic activation of dual metal centers. Notably, the secondary peak at 1.45 V vs. RHE exhibits broadening, with its position centered between the Ni4+ oxidation potential in NiO@NF (1.42 V vs. RHE) and the Co4+ oxidation potential in Co3O4@NF (1.47 V vs. RHE). This broadening is attributed to the overlap of Ni4+ and Co4+ oxidation signals due to their narrow redox potential difference (∼30 mV), resulting in an unresolved merged peak. Under GOR condition, the disappearance of metal-centered redox peaks (Fig. 3a) confirms that Ni/Co active sites directly participate in glucose electrooxidation rather than stepwise oxidation. NiCo2O4@NF demonstrates superior GOR activity, achieving benchmark current densities of 5 mA cm−2 at 1.19 V vs. RHE, 10 mA cm−2 at 1.22 V vs. RHE, 25 mA cm−2 at 1.26 V vs. RHE, 50 mA cm−2 at 1.30 V vs. RHE (Fig. 3b), significantly outperforming Co3O4@NF and NiO@NF. This enhanced performance is attributed to its hierarchical nanosheet architecture and optimized charge redistribution, which improve interfacial charge transfer and reactant accessibility. Tafel slopes further corroborate the kinetic superiority of NiCo2O4@NF, yielding the lowest Tafel slope of NiCo2O4@NF (59.2 mV dec−1) compared to Co3O4@NF (64.9 mV dec−1) and NiO@NF (73.0 mV dec−1), suggesting accelerated reaction kinetics (Fig. 3c). The improved kinetics is also reflected in double-layer capacitance (C dl) measurements (Fig. 3d, S9), where NiCo2O4@NF exhibits a significantly higher C dl value (40 mF cm−2) than Co3O4@NF (34.6 mF cm−2) and NiO@NF (13.3 mF cm−2). Post-stability tests demonstrate stable C dl values for NiCo2O4@NF and NiO@NF after 4 h of GOR operation at 1.35 V vs. RHE, whereas Co3O4@NF undergoes a pronounced decline to 11.2 mF cm−2 (Fig. S10). This contrast underscores the critical role of Ni in stabilizing the spinel framework through strong Ni–O–Co bonding networks [45], that effectively preserve structural integrity and maintain the stability of catalytically active centers. To explore the catalytic selectivity of NiCo2O4@NF during GOR, chronoamperometric tests were conducted at 1.25 V and 1.35 V vs. RHE in a single-chamber electrolytic cell. Liquid products analyzed by 1H-NMR spectroscopy identified FA as the primary product, with glycolic acid (GLA), lactic acid (LA), and trace acetic acid (AA) detected as byproducts (Figs. S11 and S12). To quantify non-selective oxidation pathways, the total byproduct yield was calculated as the sum of GLA, LA, and AA yields (Eq. S1). Remarkably, NiCo2O4@NF exhibits markedly lower total byproduct yields than NiO@NF and Co3O4@NF, demonstrating superior selectivity toward FA synthesis. Consistent with this observation, it achieves higher initial current densities (Fig. S13a, b), indicating accelerated reaction kinetics. Potential-dependent FA yield analysis showed progressive FA accumulation at 1.25 V across all catalysts, with NiCo2O4@NF achieving a maximum yield of 70.7% after 5 h (Fig. S13c). At 1.35 V, NiCo2O4@NF rapidly achieved 80.7% FA yield within 2 h before slight decline (Fig. S13d), suggesting initial rate enhancement followed by overoxidation. To elucidate the FA overoxidation pathway, dedicated chronoamperometric experiments at 1.35 V were conducted using NiCo2O4@NF in 1.0 M NaOH containing FA for 4 h. Immediate post-electrolysis ion chromatography (IC) analysis revealed time-dependent accumulation of CO3 2− and HCO3 −, evidenced by progressively increasing peak areas (Fig. S14a, b). Complementary quantitative 1H-NMR spectroscopy showed a 23.5% FA concentration decrease through attenuation of the characteristic formate proton signal at 8.4 ppm (Fig. S14c, d). For NiO@NF and Co3O4@NF, FA yields increased linearly with charge accumulation but remained significantly lower than NiCo2O4@NF (Fig. S15a, b). Their byproduct yields were substantially higher and increased rapidly with charge input (Fig. S15c, d), reflecting inefficient suppression of non-selective oxidation. Conversely, NiCo2O4@NF maintained high charge utilization efficiency and minimal byproduct generation at elevated charge inputs, emphasizing its advantages in selective GOR. To further quantify competition between target FA synthesis and side reactions, we introduced the byproduct selectivity index (BSI), defined as the ratio of total byproduct yield to FA yield (Eq. S2). As shown in Fig. S16, Co3O4@NF maintained the highest BSI (increasing at 1.35 V), while NiCo2O4@NF achieved the lowest (decreasing with potential). This confirms elevated potential exacerbates side reactions in Co3O4@NF but suppresses them in Ni-containing catalysts through Ni-regulated oxidation pathways. A broader potential evaluation showed NiCo2O4@NF consistently outperforming NiO@NF and Co3O4@NF in FA yield (Fig. S17). However, once the potential exceeded 1.40 V vs. RHE, FA yields dropped sharply for all catalysts, confirming prevalent overoxidation. To assess practical applicability, we subsequently evaluated performance at 1.35 V under industrially relevant glucose concentrations (Fig. S18). At 50 mM glucose, FA yield reached 72.5% within 4 h, increasing to 78.1% after 12 h. For 100 mM glucose, FA yield attained 62.5% at 8 h and 67% at 14 h. These results confirm sustained catalytic efficiency under high-substrate conditions where mass transport limitations intensify. Building on the selectivity findings, comparative analysis of FA yield and FE reveals distinct performance differences among the catalysts. At 1.25 V vs. RHE, Co3O4@NF exhibited the highest FE (74.8%) within the first hour, likely due to its initial preferential FA formation (Fig. S19). However, NiCo2O4@NF surpassed both Co3O4@NF and NiO@NF after 1 h, sustaining FE ＞ 90% for 2 h before a slight decline (Fig. 3e, Fig. S19). At 1.35 V vs. RHE, NiCo2O4@NF consistently achieved the highest FE (nearly 100% at 1 h and 91.3% at 2 h), whereas Co3O4@NF showed the lowest FE (∼60%) with negligible improvement over time. This performance aligns with its abrupt reduction in C dl value after reaction (Fig. S10), likely caused by progressive surface passivation due to strong adsorption of accumulated byproducts (Figs. S15 and S16). To further probe catalytic selectivity under optimal GOR conditions, in situ Raman spectra were monitored over 60 min at 1.35 V vs. RHE (Fig. S20). A prominent glucose-associated peak appeared across all catalysts within 5 min, confirming initial adsorption. While NiO@NF and Co3O4@NF exhibit no further spectral evolution, NiCo2O4@NF displays a characteristic FA-associated peak (1450 cm−1) after 30 min [46], directly corroborating its superior pathway selectivity. To comprehensively assess the integrated GOR-HER system, the hydrogen evolution at the Pt cathode was quantified via GC in a three-electrode H-cell configuration (Fig. S21). No detectable H2 signal was observed without applied bias, confirming the absence of thermocatalytic activity under ambient conditions (Fig. S22). Experimentally measured H2 yield at 1.25 and 1.35 V vs. RHE closely matched theoretical values (>95%, as calculated by Eq. (6) based on total charge transfer during electrolysis (Fig. 3f). The H2 production efficiency followed the hierarchy: NiCo2O4@NF > Co3O4@NF > NiO@NF, corroborating that Ni-Co synergy enhances both GOR selectivity and overall charge utilization for coupled hydrogen generation. To evaluate long-term catalytic robustness under industrially relevant conditions, scaled-up stability tests were conducted in a 420 mL electrolyte system (14× volumetric scale-up) over five consecutive 12-hour cycles (60 h total) at 1.35 V vs. RHE, with complete electrolyte replacement between cycles. While all catalysts maintained measurable activity without severe deactivation (Fig. S23), significant performance divergences emerged: NiCo2O4@NF exhibited superior current recovery after electrolyte refresh and sustained the highest current density across all cycles, whereas NiO@NF showed limited reactivation and Co3O4@NF demonstrated minimal recovery with consistently low activity. SEM images confirmed that NiCo2O4@NF retained its interconnected wrinkle-like nanosheet architecture without observable agglomeration or structural collapse (Fig. S24). EDS elemental mapping further revealed a uniform distribution of Ni, Co, O elements (Fig. S24), thereby confirming its compositional stability. Collectively, these results demonstrate the exceptional operational stability of NiCo2O4@NF during prolonged industrial-scale operation, validating Ni-Co synergism as indispensable for practical glucose oxidation systems. Table S4 summarizes key performance metrics of other bimetallic catalysts reported over the past three years, with comparative data for NiCo2O4@NF demonstrating its superior catalytic performance under equivalent reaction conditions. To uncover the mechanistic origins of this exceptional performance and the underlying Ni-Co interactions, operando EIS and in situ Raman spectroscopy were conducted across a wide potential range to track the dynamic evolution of active sites, aiming to clarify the correlation between structural changes and catalytic selectivity. 3.3 Tracking potential-dependent dynamics of active sites and their correlation with GOR selectivity via operando EIS and in situ Raman spectroscopy Operando EIS was conducted over a wide potential range (1.0–1.7 V vs. RHE) to analyze the interfacial charge transfer dynamics underlying the exceptional GOR performance of NiCo2O4@NF (Fig. 4 ). Impedance spectra were modeled using an optimized equivalent circuit (Fig. S25) to distinguish interfacial and bulk charge transfer processes during OER and GOR [47]. In Bode phase plots (Fig. 4a–c, Fig. S26), the low frequency region (10−2–101 Hz) corresponds to heterogeneous charge distribution induced by oxidized species formation on the electrode surface [48], while the high frequency region (>101 Hz) reflects rapid bulk-phase electrode oxidation and charge transfer kinetics [49]. As the applied potential increased from 1.0 to 1.4 V vs. RHE, peaks associated with adsorbed OH* intermediates shifted to lower frequencies with decreasing phase angles (Fig. S26), indicating progressive evolution of surface redox states. At 1.5 V (1.6 V for NiO@NF) vs. RHE, a secondary peak emerged near 0.1 Hz for Co3O4@NF and NiCo2O4@NF, signifying OER activation via electrochemical oxidation of Co2+/Ni2+ to active CoOOH/NiOOH phases [50]. Upon glucose introduction, GOR-specific peaks appeared at 1.1 V vs. RHE for all catalysts, approximately 400–500 mV below the OER onset (Fig. 4a–c). These peaks shifted to higher frequencies with decreased phase angles as the potential increased, demonstrating the kinetic preference for GOR over OER. Notably, NiCo2O4@NF exhibits the smallest phase angle (Fig. 4c, Fig. S26c) and minimum Nyquist semicircle radii across all potentials (Fig. S27), further confirming its superior charge transfer kinetics. Fitted EIS parameters provide insights into interfacial and bulk charge transfer dynamics (Fig. 4d–f, Figs. S28 and S29). Here, R ct (interfacial charge transfer resistance) and R p (polarization resistance) correspond to surface reaction kinetics and bulk lattice redox transitions, respectively. At 1.0 V vs. RHE, direct GOR occurs via glucose adsorption without involving high-valent Ni/Co species [51], leading to a sharp decrease in R ct (Fig. 4d). Above 1.1 V vs. RHE, R ct further decreases as progressively oxidized Ni/Co species mediated the reaction, while a reduction in R p indicates accelerated bulk redox kinetics (Fig. 4e). R ct values in glucose-free electrolyte (1.0 M NaOH) remain significantly higher than those under GOR conditions (Fig. 4f), confirming sluggish charge transfer in pure alkaline media before OER activation at 1.5 V vs. RHE. NiCo2O4@NF exhibits the lowest R ct across all potentials, highlighting efficient charge transfer enabled by synergistic Ni–Co interactions. Capacitance fitting further reveals distinct interfacial and bulk dielectric responses. NiCo2O4@NF shows elevated double-layer capacitance (CPE1) and bulk dielectric response (CPE2) compared to NiO@NF and Co3O4@NF (Fig. S29), signifying enhanced surface charge storage capacity. Overall, these attributes underscore the optimized surface reactivity and bulk conductivity of NiCo2O4@NF, which facilitate earlier GOR onset and suppress OER interference. While EIS analysis unveils charge transfer advantages of NiCo2O4@NF, it does not identify the catalytically active species or their potential-dependent evolution during GOR. To address this gap, in situ Raman spectroscopy was systematically employed to probe structural dynamics of catalysts and identify key intermediates governing the enhanced performance. In situ Raman spectra acquired at different potentials reveal distinct surface reconstruction characteristics of the catalysts during OER and GOR. Under OER conditions, NiO@NF exhibits progressive oxidation of Ni2+ to Ni3+, as evidenced by increasing LO mode intensity (associated with Ni–O2− lattice vibrations) from open-circuit potential (OCP) to 1.4 V vs. RHE (Fig. S30). This aligns with LSV analysis showing a distinct Ni2+ → Ni3+ oxidation peak at 1.36–1.41 V vs. RHE (Fig. 3a). Above 1.4 V vs. RHE, characteristic NiOOH vibrational bands emerged at 480 and 557 cm−1 (Fig. S30a), confirming surface reconstruction into more active NiOOH phases [52]. Conversely, Co3O4@NF exhibits limited surface reconstruction. At low-to-moderate potentials (<1.4 V vs. RHE), its characteristic vibrational modes gradually attenuated (Fig. S30b), while O–H stretching signals intensified. This implies strong adsorption of OH* that suppressed Raman scattering efficiency, suggesting sluggish oxidation kinetics. At higher potentials (≥1.4 V vs. RHE), only a weak Eg bending band of CoOOH appeared at 455 cm−1 with minimal intensity variations [53] (Fig. S30b), suggesting restricted phase transitions to near-surface regions [54]. From OCP to 1.4 V vs. RHE, NiCo2O4@NF displays markedly intensified vibrational modes (Fig. S30c), signifying efficient co-activation of Ni2+ and Co3+ species. At 1.5 V vs. RHE, two distinct bands emerged at 446 cm−1 (Eg bending vibration of O–Co–O in CoOOH) and 527 cm−1 (F2g stretching vibration of O–Ni–O in NiOOH), while the A1g mode of Co–O2− at 650 cm−1 attenuated sharply. These changes reflect voltage-driven oxidation of Co to CoOOH and Ni to NiOOH. At 1.6 V vs. RHE, the NiOOH signal intensified while the CoOOH signal diminished, with a new peak at 461 cm−1 assigned to CoO2 species [54]. This suggests that surface reconstruction primarily occurred at octahedral Co sites, where Ni incorporation facilitates their transformation into highly active CoOOH and CoO2 intermediates for OER. Notably, all high-valent species (NiOOH, CoOOH and CoO2) vanished upon glucose addition (Fig. S30), confirming their rapid consumption by nucleophilic glucose [55]. Under GOR condition, the structural evolution of the catalysts diverged significantly from OER. At low-to-moderate potentials (<1.4 V vs. RHE), the decreased LO mode intensity in NiO@NF and attenuated A1g mode intensity in Co3O4@NF (Fig. 4g–i) suggest direct participation of intermediate-valent Ni and Co species in GOR. Even at higher potentials (≥1.4 V vs. RHE), NiO@NF shows only weak NiOOH vibrational bands at 470 cm−1 with increased LO mode intensity (Fig. 4g), while Co3O4@NF shows enhanced O–H stretching signals without notable surface reconstruction (Fig. 4h). In contrast, NiCo2O4@NF exhibits progressively intensified vibrational signals with increasing potential (Fig. 4i), showing continuous activation of additional active sites. At 1.4 V vs. RHE, simultaneous enhancement of NiOOH and Co–O2− signals suggest concurrent oxidation of both metal centers. By 1.5 V vs. RHE, weak CoO2 signals emerged alongside diminishing Co–O2− signals, indicating partial conversion of Co to CoO2. At 1.6 V vs. RHE, intensified CoO2 and NiOOH peaks confirm sustained activation of tetrahedral Ni to generate NiOOH, which further promote adjacent Co oxidation to CoO2. However, these high-valent species are suboptimal for selective FA production due to their excessively oxidative activity driving FA overoxidation (Figs. S14 and S17). Instead, intermediate-valent Ni3+ and Co3+ species dominate catalytic activity at moderate potentials, balancing reactivity and selectivity. The glucose adsorption peak (1353 cm−1) emerged earliest in NiCo2O4@NF and latest in NiO@NF (Fig. 4g–i), implicating octahedral Co sites as key active centers for glucose adsorption and conversion. In summary, Ni incorporation into the spinel framework facilitates octahedral Co activation, thereby enhancing both glucose adsorption and selective oxidation. Surface reconstruction during OER generates high-valent species optimized for water oxidation but detrimental to selective glucose oxidation, whereas GOR selectivity is maximized at moderate potentials where intermediate-valent Co3+ species dominate. To further unravel the atomic-scale mechanistic origin of the Ni-Co synergistic effect, NEXAFS measurements and DFT calculations are employed in the following section. 3.4 Unraveling spin-state transition and Ni-Co synergistic mechanism via NEXAFS spectra and DFT calculations To investigate the origin of Ni-Co synergy in NiCo2O4@NF, we conducted Co L-edge and O K-edge NEXAFS measurements to differentiate the electronic structures of NiCo2O4 and Co3O4. Transition metal L-edge NEXAFS exhibits high sensitivity to oxidation states, spin configurations, and orbital occupancy changes [56]. As shown in Fig. 5a , the Co L-edge spectra are partitioned into L3 (2p 3/2 levels → unoccupied 3d orbitals) and L2 (2p 1/2 → 3d) transition regions [57]. Co3O4 exhibits characteristic peaks for Co and Co, confirming its spinel configuration [Co(Co)2O4] [58]. O K-edge NEXAFS (Fig. 5b) probes Co 3d-O 2p hybridization via O 1s → 2p transitions hybridized with Co 3d states [59], where spectral features at 528–533 eV correspond to t 2g/e g orbitals, while peaks at 535–550 eV arise from O 2p-Co 4s/4p hybridization [60]. Co3O4 shows an intense e g peak without discernible t 2g features, consistent with low-spin Co (LS, te) [58]. Conversely, NiCo2O4 exhibits distinct changes in the Co L-edge multiplet structure, characterized by an intensified peak associated with Co species and a diminished feature attributed to Co. Its O K-edge spectrum reveals reduced intensity at 530–533 eV with enhanced peak splitting, indicating increased 3d-band splitting [59]. A 0.2 eV negative shift of the e g peak (530.3 vs. 530.5 eV in Co3O4) signifies elevated e g orbital occupancy. Furthermore, a distinct t 2g orbital peak was observed, further confirming electron transfer from t 2g to e g orbitals [61]. Collectively, these NEXAFS features provide direct spectral evidence for the electronic reconfiguration of Co from low-spin to intermediate-spin (IS, te), unequivocally confirming Ni-induced spin-state transition. Our study indicates that the Ni-Co synergistic effect driving the spin-state transition is further accompanied by elevated Vo concentration (Fig. S4), implying that Vo may act as an additional key factor contributing to the high FA selectivity [15]. To elucidate the distinct roles of Vo and spin-state engineering in governing catalytic performance, we synthesized Vo-modulated NiCo2O4@NF via O2 annealing. EPR quantification confirmed 32.0% Vo reduction versus air-annealed counterparts (Fig. 5c). Electrochemical analysis revealed that Vo reduction shifted metal oxidation peaks to more positive potentials as observed in 1.0 M NaOH (Fig. 5d), indicating elevated energy barriers for Ni/Co oxidation. During GOR, Vo reduction impaired charge transfer kinetics, as evidenced by a 45.5 mV overpotential increase required to reach 70 mA cm−2 above 1.27 V vs. RHE (Fig. 5e). Crucially, quantitative analysis after GOR tests at 1.35 V showed that the FE for FA production remained stable under Vo-reduced conditions (Fig. 5f). These results indicate that Vo primarily accelerates charge transport without altering reaction selectivity, highlighting its role in enhancing catalytic activity through improved charge carrier density. In contrast, the Ni-Co synergistic effect mediated by spin-state engineering fundamentally governs high FA selectivity. To further elucidate the Ni-Co synergy at atomic level, systematic DFT calculations were performed. Based on the experimental results, octahedral Co within the pristine spinel framework is identified as the dominant active center rather than high-valent Co species, which differs from previous studies [62,63]. Thus, DFT models were constructed based on the original catalyst structure rather than surface-reconstructed phases. Given the thermodynamic stability and limited activity of dominantly exposed surfaces, optimized models of NiO with (220) facet, Co3O4 with (440) facet, and NiCo2O4 with (440) facet corresponding to secondary exposed planes were constructed to investigate catalytic activity differences (Figs. S31–36). Comparative bond length analysis reveals distinct lattice strain effects (Table S5). NiO exhibits ionic Ni2+–O2− bonding (2.093 Å), while Co3O4 shows shorter covalent bonds at tetrahedral Co ([CoO4], 1.924 Å) and octahedral Co ([CoO6], 1.912 Å). In NiCo2O4, tetrahedral Ni–O2− bonds (2.000 Å) display intermediate lengths between NiO (Ni2+–O2−) and Co3O4 (Co–O2−), implying Ni-induced lattice strain. Critically, the octahedral Co–O2− bond (1.911 Å) retains robust covalent character, ensuring active site stability. This non-uniform bond contraction is hypothesized to promote charge redistribution and electronic structure modulation [64]. Electron localization function (ELF) and Bader charge analyses elucidate strain-mediated charge redistribution (Fig. 6a , Fig. S37). In NiO, strong electron confinement around oxygen atoms reflects ionic bonding that restricts charge mobility. In contrast, Co3O4 exhibits partial delocalization at octahedral Co sites, evidenced by reduced oxygen-centered ELF values. NiCo2O4 displays the lowest oxygen-centered ELF, where lattice strain polarizes bridging oxygen atoms to facilitate charge transfer toward adjacent Co sites. Quantitative Bader charge analysis corroborates this mechanism (Table S6, Fig. 6b). NiO shows symmetric charge transfer (Ni2+: +1.192 e; O2−: −1.192 e), while Co3O4 shows enhanced charge transfer at tetrahedral Co (7.681, +1.319 e) and octahedral Co (7.526, +1.474 e) sites with incomplete oxygen charge compensation (7.080, −1.134 e). In NiCo2O4, tetrahedral Ni (8.913, +1.087 e) polarizes bridging oxygen ligands (6.957, −0.957 e), establishing a covalent Ni → O → Co charge-transfer network that stabilizes active Co species (7.691, +1.309 e). This charge redistribution optimizes the electronic environment for catalysis. Partial density of states (PDOS) analysis further clarifies the electronic origins of enhanced activity (Fig. 6c–e). NiCo2O4 exhibits intensified electronic states near the Fermi level (E f) compared to NiO and Co3O4, indicative of improved charge transfer efficiency [65]. The pronounced overlap between Co 3d and O 2p orbitals (vs. Ni 3d-O 2p) confirms stronger Co–O covalent bonding and electron delocalization (Fig. 6e). The calculated d-band center of NiCo2O4 (−1.80 eV) lies closer to Ef than NiO (−3.84 eV) and slightly below Co3O4 (−1.63 eV) (Fig. S38), achieving an optimal balance between reactant adsorption strength and product desorption feasibility [66]. This electronic restructuring induces a spin-state transition in octahedral Co (Fig. 6f, Fig. S39), evidenced by magnetic moment analysis. A marked increase from 0.09 μB in Co3O4 to 2.01 μB in NiCo2O4 was observed (Table S7), indicating a transition from low-spin Co3+ (te, 0 μB) to intermediate-spin Co3+ (te, 2.83 μB) [67]. Enhanced spin polarization ratios (P(e g): 0.096 → 0.201; P(t 2g): 0.132 → 0.206) reflect increased unpaired electron density, which further confirm the spin-state transition (Fig. S40). The intermediate-spin state of Co3+ optimizes its e g orbital occupancy [68], enhancing the adsorption of glucose for efficient GOR [69]. In contrast, high-spin Co4+ (te, 4.9 μB) species generated at higher potentials exhibit excessive activity that destabilize selective FA production [59,61]. Adsorption energy calculations corroborate this structural-electronic synergy (Fig. 6g). NiCo2O4 achieves exceptional glucose adsorption energy (−11.9 eV) at octahedral Co sites, representing an order-of-magnitude improvement over NiO (−0.949 eV) and Co3O4 (tetrahedral: −2.64 eV; octahedral: −2.35 eV). This finding aligns with in situ Raman observations of earlier glucose adsorption onset (Fig. 6g inset). Furthermore, these experimental and theoretical data elucidate the mechanism by which NiCo2O4@NF suppresses side reaction pathways: the tetrahedral Ni-induced transition of octahedral Co3+ to an intermediate-spin state enhances glucose adsorption via elevated e g orbital occupancy. This electronic configuration strengthens orbital hybridization with electron-donating functional groups in glucose and reduces chemisorption activation barriers, thereby accelerating kinetic commitment to the FA pathway through selective substrate activation. This spin-state optimization of octahedral Co establishes a multiscale regulatory mechanism within NiCo2O4, thereby rationalizing its superior electrocatalytic activity and FA selectivity. 4 Conclusions In this work, we elucidated Ni-Co synergy in NiCo2O4@NF, where tetrahedral Ni induces a low-spin (0 μB) to intermediate-spin (2.01 μB) transition via a Ni → O → Co charge transfer network. DFT calculations confirm that the spin-state modulation enhances e g orbital occupancy of Co3+, improving interfacial charge transport kinetics and glucose adsorption and activation on NiCo2O4 surface. The engineered NiCo2O4@NF catalyst exhibits exceptional electrocatalytic performance, achieving a current density of 50 mA cm−2 at 1.30 V vs. RHE with a low Tafel slope (59.2 mV dec−1), significantly outperforming NiO@NF and Co3O4@NF. Operando analysis demonstrates a potential-dependent dynamic evolution of active species. Selective catalysis of the glucose oxidation reaction is primarily controlled by intermediate-spin octahedral Co sites at low-to-moderate potentials (<1.4 V vs. RHE), while OER activity at higher potentials is driven by the formation of high-valent CoOOH/CoO2 species, which lead to glucose overoxidation. As a result, NiCo2O4@NF achieves an 80.7% FA yield with 91.3% FE within 2 h at 1.35 V. This system also enables coupled H2 production at the cathode (696 μmol h−1, 99.9% FE), demonstrating the feasibility of energy-efficient biomass valorization. This work provides guidance for designing spinel catalysts that leverage spin-orbital interactions to balance reactivity and selectivity. These findings advance the understanding of transition metal oxide electrocatalysis and offer a scalable approach for sustainable biomass valorization. coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalytic glucose oxidation to high-value chemicals provides a sustainable route for biomass valorization. NiCo-based catalysts have emerged as promising candidates for glucose oxidation reaction owing to the intrinsic activity of Ni and Co catalytic centers. However, the dynamic evolution and atomic-scale synergy between these centers remain elusive. Herein, we fabricated NiCo2O4 nanosheets supported on nickel foam, where Ni preferentially occupies tetrahedral sites to regulate the electronic configuration of octahedral Co. Experimental and theoretical results demonstrate that the incorporation of tetrahedral Ni induces low-to-intermediate spin transition in octahedral Co, thereby optimizing e g orbital occupancy and stabilizing active sites. This spin-state engineering establishes Ni-Co synergistic catalytic centers for the selective oxidation of glucose to formic acid. At higher potential (≥1.4 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode), octahedral Co undergoes reconstruction into excessive active CoOOH and CoO2 species, resulting in glucose overoxidation to CO2 and intensified competitive oxygen evolution. In contrast, at lower potentials (<1.4 V), tetrahedral Ni facilitates electron delocalization across the Ni–O–Co lattice, thereby stabilizing octahedral Co for glucose adsorption and oxidation. Subsequently, a coupled electrocatalytic system was constructed, achieving 80.7% formic acid yield with 91.3% Faradaic efficiency at NiCo2O4 anode and H2 evolution rate of 696 μmol h−1 with 99.9% Faradaic efficiency at Pt cathode for 2 h under 1.35 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode. This work provides a deep insight into spin-state regulation of the catalytic center, offering valuable guidance for rational catalyst design.
